# Analysis of âš¡â”‚general Discord Channel

## 1. Summary:
The discussion primarily revolves around Hyperfy's transition from v1 to v2, with a focus on onboarding challenges for new users. Community members discussed the need for better entry points for non-technical users to start building in Hyperfy. Several solutions were proposed, including creating a starter pack with pre-installed apps from v1, developing a more informative homepage, and providing easier hosting options. There was mention of Hyperball, a game that could potentially be added to worlds. The conversation also touched on the technical capability of applying physics force to push players, which could be used in games. Some members compared Hyperfy's approach to Roblox, suggesting that creators could benefit from keeping all their profits by using Hyperfy instead. Hosting solutions were shared, including a free server setup tutorial and a hosting service called HyperWorld.Host.

Q: How to deploy in Hyperfy? (asked by Cybermike) A: Check out the #getting-started channel for info and there's a YouTube tutorial for setting up a free server (answered by BallisticBanana and ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“)
Q: What is the utility of the hyper token? (asked by Asik) A: Unanswered

## 3. Help Interactions:

## 4. Action Items:
Technical Tasks: Description: Create a starter pack with pre-installed v1 apps for v2 | Mentioned By: mrtzhckr and ash
Technical Tasks: Description: Implement physics force to push players for games like Hyperball | Mentioned By: Valiant
Documentation Needs: Description: Develop a v2 homepage with clear onboarding instructions | Mentioned By: untitled, xyz
Documentation Needs: Description: Create a frontend showcase of available worlds/games similar to Hytopia | Mentioned By: Dhin
Feature Requests: Description: Add Hyperball to available worlds | Mentioned By: ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“
Feature Requests: Description: Develop a solution that balances ease of use with user ownership of worlds | Mentioned By: ash

The chat segment is very brief, containing only two messages. Valiant shared a WebGPU water rendering demo, highlighting the visual quality of water in WebGPU. Later, ash shared a link to sprites.dev and mentioned successfully running Hyperfy (presumably a 3D/WebGL application) on the platform in approximately three minutes, suggesting it's a quick deployment solution for web-based 3D applications.
